feed.title: Combined summary - Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam

entry.title: Combined summary - Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
entry.summary:
The discussion centers around a proposal to tackle the scalability challenge posed by the Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO) set's expansion, primarily attributed to spam activities. The UTXO set, crucial for validating new transactions and determining wallet balances, has significantly grown due to various factors including inscription spam attacks, BRC-20 token scams, and wash trading. This growth from 4.6 GB to 11 GB since 2023 not only strains full node operators but also raises concerns about the network's long-term viability.
A soft fork proposal introduces an innovative approach to mitigate this issue by expiring very small and very old outputs based on a predetermined age threshold. This method aims to prune these "dust" UTXOs from the set, thus reducing its size and alleviating the bloat caused by spam. The proposal suggests that once UTXOs reach a state of expiration—dictated by their size relative to the dust limit—they become unspendable and can be removed. This strategy is anticipated to clean up the UTXO set effectively, making the system more efficient and scalable.
However, the proposal has sparked a debate regarding its implications on Bitcoin's trust model. Critics argue that arbitrarily making certain UTXOs unspendable alters the foundational promise of Bitcoin—that as long as individuals possess the private keys, their holdings are secure regardless of the UTXO's size or age. Concerns have been raised about the potential impact on long-term holders, forgotten wallets, and low-income users who might disproportionately suffer from such changes. The discussion highlights the need for solutions that address UTXO set bloat without compromising Bitcoin’s core principles of autonomy and ownership.
In response to these concerns, an alternative approach has been suggested. Instead of outright expiration, the proposal recommends making very small, very old outputs prunable while retaining their location data within the blockchain. This would allow users to spend their UTXOs by providing a Simple Payment Verification (SPV) proof of the transaction that created the UTXO. By shifting the data storage burden from the global UTXO set to individual users, this method aims to preserve user autonomy and reduce spam without resorting to protocol-level confiscation.
This ongoing dialogue reflects the community's efforts to balance scalability improvements with the preservation of Bitcoin's decentralization and user sovereignty. As the proposal undergoes further scrutiny and refinement, it underscores the complexities involved in evolving a decentralized network like Bitcoin in the face of growing technical challenges.
